talk.author: did:plc:vzon6fjfmnjcaksqbfk7hjlk
talk.utter: My ancestors had some great names: e.g. Euphemia Ballantyne; Unity Hyett, Felix Gunn.  My favourite is Esther Ferry, who after she died was misnamed on the family grave - due no doubt to her Donegal accent - as Easter Fairry.  I love these quirky names. Please tell me more.

talk.author: did:plc:nknkvxcw2l5oi3l5yifqagaq
talk.utter:
My Scottish grandfather was Charles Archibald MacDonald...Charlie
My Irish grandmother was Emmaline American Gay.
I had great Aunts: Fanny, Maise, Myrtle, and Ossie. great Uncles Thaddeus, Matthew, Edward, and Ezekiel.

talk.author: did:plc:vzon6fjfmnjcaksqbfk7hjlk
talk.utter: Ah the old names were so good!   Was Ossie a shortening?  What of?  I had great aunties Flora and Bella.  In Northern Ireland some of the older names persist: Maureen, Olive, Maud.

talk.author: did:plc:vzon6fjfmnjcaksqbfk7hjlk
talk.utter: Ah the old names were so good!   Was Ossie a shortening?  What of?  I had great aunties Flora and Bella.  In Northern Ireland some of the older names persist: Maureen, Olive, Maud.

talk.author: did:plc:nknkvxcw2l5oi3l5yifqagaq
talk.utter: I remember my mom once saying that Ossie's given name was Osla. The "O" in Ossie was pronounced like the "O" in "Ophelia. And incorrect autocorrect "corrected" my grandma's middle name to "American"...it was actually America.

talk.author: did:plc:vzon6fjfmnjcaksqbfk7hjlk
talk.utter: Wow, what an interesting name.

talk.author: did:plc:vzon6fjfmnjcaksqbfk7hjlk
talk.utter: Wow, what an interesting name.

talk.author: did:plc:nknkvxcw2l5oi3l5yifqagaq
talk.utter: My great grandmother's name was Emmaline American Dukes Gay. I love the sound of those names, but I'm grateful that they didn't make it to my generation. Doris Anne is bad enough, but my sister was named after my dad...Wilma Earleen.

talk.author: did:plc:vzon6fjfmnjcaksqbfk7hjlk
talk.utter: I'm a Dorothy.  My dad was George and my mother's middle name was Georgina and her mother was Georgina and known as Georgia.  I'd have killed to be called Georgia but it wasn't to be.

talk.author: did:plc:vzon6fjfmnjcaksqbfk7hjlk
talk.utter: I'm a Dorothy.  My dad was George and my mother's middle name was Georgina and her mother was Georgina and known as Georgia.  I'd have killed to be called Georgia but it wasn't to be.

talk.author: did:plc:nknkvxcw2l5oi3l5yifqagaq
talk.utter:
I love the sound and rhythm of Dorothy, and the way Georgina and Georgia just stake a claim on a woman's right to strength. And auto-boob did me in again...
The middle names were AMERICA...and AMERICANA for Emma and Emmaline. GG, autocorrect!

talk.author: did:plc:vzon6fjfmnjcaksqbfk7hjlk
talk.utter: I've grown into Dorothy as I got older.  And autocorrect drives me mad too! üòÜ

talk.author: did:plc:vzon6fjfmnjcaksqbfk7hjlk
talk.utter: I've grown into Dorothy as I got older.  And autocorrect drives me mad too! üòÜ

talk.author: did:plc:nknkvxcw2l5oi3l5yifqagaq
talk.utter: I'm still at odds with Doris, but I've learned to live with it. üòÅ

talk.author: did:plc:vzon6fjfmnjcaksqbfk7hjlk
talk.utter: I was going to write it has to be done  but I guess it doesn't.  I couldn't be bothered changing though. There are worse things to worry about üôÇ

talk.author: did:plc:vzon6fjfmnjcaksqbfk7hjlk
talk.utter: My ancestors had some great names: e.g. Euphemia Ballantyne; Unity Hyett, Felix Gunn.  My favourite is Esther Ferry, who after she died was misnamed on the family grave - due no doubt to her Donegal accent - as Easter Fairry.  I love these quirky names. Please tell me more.

talk.author: did:plc:ndryaheowcfetmxyibosrn2o
talk.utter: What a great thread! Thank you! I‚Äôm going to my dad‚Äôs parents‚Äô birthplace Matera, Italy in April for the first time. Really want to do some family history while I‚Äôm there. I know there are relatives on the Pisciotta side but I want to learn more about the Nicolettis.

talk.author: did:plc:vzon6fjfmnjcaksqbfk7hjlk
talk.utter: Matera!  Wow, I was there at the end of October: Matera, Alberobello, Lecce.   It was a walking week.  The food is so good everywhere there.  The first week in Matera my friend and I walked down a flight of stone steps into the old town about 7pm and the bells were ringing. It was so spooky!

talk.author: did:plc:vzon6fjfmnjcaksqbfk7hjlk
talk.utter: Sorry, the first night in Matera.  The old town is a wonderful maze of discovery.  The people are lovely.

talk.author: did:plc:vzon6fjfmnjcaksqbfk7hjlk
talk.utter: Matera!  Wow, I was there at the end of October: Matera, Alberobello, Lecce.   It was a walking week.  The food is so good everywhere there.  The first week in Matera my friend and I walked down a flight of stone steps into the old town about 7pm and the bells were ringing. It was so spooky!

talk.author: did:plc:vzon6fjfmnjcaksqbfk7hjlk
talk.utter: Sorry, the first night in Matera.  The old town is a wonderful maze of discovery.  The people are lovely.

talk.author: did:plc:ndryaheowcfetmxyibosrn2o
talk.utter: I think there was a time when they were trying to improve the slums that the sassi became over time, you could claim a home if you could prove it was your family‚Äôs.. sad we missed out on that, if true. How wonderful that you‚Äôve been there!

talk.author: did:plc:vzon6fjfmnjcaksqbfk7hjlk
talk.utter: Trying to remember now what I was told ... I think it emptied out in the mid 20th century because it was unliveable.   Then, about the 80s, people were encouraged to come back and create liveable homes.  Similar schemes ran in other abandoned Italian villages I believe.

talk.author: did:plc:vzon6fjfmnjcaksqbfk7hjlk
talk.utter: Some small villages further north have become hybrid hotels. You stay in a village house and eat in cafes and restaurants in the village.  Not all the houses are owned by the 'hotel' but it provides work and business opportunities for those who are still there.
